9490;coderabbitai[bot];<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: summarize by coderabbit.ai -->

Adds nested workspace fixtures and updates analyze recursion: `analyzeEntry` and `captureDependenciesToOptimize` now accept and propagate an `initialDepsToOptimize` map through recursive calls; tests and mocks updated to exercise recursive transitive workspace resolution.

column3: Adds a patch changelog entry noting improved analyze recursion in the bundler for monorepos.
Adds a three-package nested workspace fixture (app, internal package, shared package) with ESM manifests and simple exports/imports to simulate transitive workspace dependencies.

Adds `beforeEach` to clear mocks, mocks `resolve-from` and wraps `rollup`, propagates `projectRoot`, and introduces a recursive-import test asserting transitive workspace dependencies are discovered without infinite recursion.

Adds optional `initialDepsToOptimize` parameter to `analyzeEntry` and `captureDependenciesToOptimize`, threads that map through recursive calls, and uses it instead of creating a fresh `new Map()` for transitive dependency checks.

column1: Note over captureDeps: collect direct deps seeded from initialDepsToOptimize
Note over captureDeps: for each transitive dep, recurse with same seed
- Check propagation of `initialDepsToOptimize` through all recursive call-sites and defaulting behavior.
- Verify `checkTransitiveDependencies` usage of the passed map and ensure no unintended shared-state side effects.
- Review new fixtures and test mocks (`resolve-from`, wrapped `rollup`) for accuracy and isolation.
> 🐰 I hopped through nested workspaces wide,
> Seeding maps so deps won't hide,
> Recursive calls now share the trail,
> No more loops, no wasted tail,

column4: Check skipped - CodeRabbit’s high-level summary is enabled.

The title ""Fix bundle analyze recursion"" directly addresses the primary objective of this pull request, which is to prevent redundant re-analysis of files during bundle analysis in large monorepos. The implementation adds an initialDepsToOptimize parameter to track already-analyzed dependencies throughout recursive analyses, and the title accurately captures this fix. The title is concise, clear, and specific enough that a developer scanning the commit history would understand the core change without requiring additional context.
Docstring coverage is 100.00% which is sufficient. The required threshold is 80.00%.

The `.only` modifier will skip all other tests in the suite, preventing proper CI validation.

> Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements.
test is marked with .only which causes Jest to run only this test and skip
others; remove the .only modifier so the test reads it('should handle recursive
imports', async () => { ... }) to ensure the full test suite runs in CI.
<!-- This is an auto-generated comment by CodeRabbit -->"
**Add cleanup for all modified mocks to prevent test pollution.**

The `beforeEach` only clears the `rollup` mock, but the recursive imports test (line 196) overrides `process.cwd()` and sets a `resolveFrom` implementation (lines 198-207) without cleanup. If tests run sequentially, later tests will see the modified mocks instead of the default fixture path.
Apply this diff to add comprehensive mock cleanup:
> Committable suggestion skipped: line range outside the PR's diff.
the beforeEach only clears the rollup mock but other tests modify globals
(process.cwd) and mocks (resolveFrom) without teardown; add comprehensive mock
cleanup and restoration to avoid test pollution: after each test call
clear any specific mocked modules used in this file (e.g.,
restore any spies you create on process.cwd by calling the spy's mockRestore()
(or use vi.spyOn(process, 'cwd') and mockRestore in afterEach) so each test runs
with the default fixture path and clean mock state.
<!-- This is an auto-generated comment by CodeRabbit -->

9513;coderabbitai[bot];<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: summarize by coderabbit.ai -->

Tightened a test by removing function-call related assertions in `stream.test.ts`, and made `getMessages` in `packages/core/src/storage/mock.ts` return an empty array on error instead of throwing. Both changes are internal/test-level and do not alter public APIs.

column3: Removed assertions for `function_call`, `function_call_output`, and related assistant/user message entries from the second (v2) response expected request body.
Added error handling to `getMessages`: on `memory.getMessages` failure it now catches the error and returns an empty array instead of letting the error propagate.

column1: - Inspect `stream.test.ts` to confirm removed assertions align with intended test behavior and no other tests depend on them.
- Review `getMessages` catch to ensure swallowing the error and returning `[]` is acceptable for callers and doesn't hide important failures.
- Quick run of unit tests related to agent storage and stream behaviors.
> 🐇 I nibble lines of tests and code,
> A soft catch here, a tidy expect,

column4: Docstring coverage is 0.00% which is insufficient. The required threshold is 80.00%.
column5: You can run `@coderabbitai generate docstrings` to improve docstring coverage.

column4: The title ""fix core tests"" is vague and lacks specificity about the actual changes made. While it references the core package and tests, it doesn't convey what is actually being fixed or why. The changeset includes two distinct types of modifications: tightening test expectations in stream.test.ts by removing specific assertions, and adding error handling to the getMessages method in mock.ts production code. The generic use of ""fix"" without clarification leaves a reader scanning the history uncertain about the primary objective or scope of these changes.
column5: Consider revising the title to be more descriptive and specific about the changes, such as ""Tighten stream test expectations and add error handling to mock storage"" or similar, so that the primary intent is immediately clear to team members reviewing the pull request history.

column4: Check skipped - CodeRabbit’s high-level summary is enabled.

column1: - [ ] <!-- {""checkboxId"": ""07f1e7d6-8a8e-4e23-9900-8731c2c87f58"", ""radioGroupId"": ""utg-output-choice-group-unknown_comment_id""} -->   Post copyable unit tests in a comment
<sub>Comment `@coderabbitai help` to get the list of available commands and usage tips.</sub>
**Silently suppressing errors can mask real issues and hinder debugging.**
Catching all errors and returning an empty array makes it impossible to distinguish between ""no messages found"" and ""an error occurred."" This can lead to:
- Masking legitimate bugs (invalid arguments, logic errors)
- False assumptions that there are no messages when an error actually occurred
- Tests not catching error-handling issues that would occur in production
1. **Fix the root cause**: If tests are failing due to errors, address the underlying issue rather than suppressing the error
2. **Log the error**: At minimum, log errors before returning an empty array so failures are visible
3. **Add a flag**: Return `{ messages: [], error?: Error }` to preserve error information
4. **Let it throw**: Allow errors to propagate so tests can properly verify error handling
Additionally, the `as unknown as Promise<...>` casting suggests a type mismatch that should be investigated.

Documentation updates across eight processor reference pages. Changes include title normalization, type signature updates from MastraLanguageModel to MastraModelConfig, model reference changes from function calls to string identifiers, documentation formatting, and related link updates to Guardrails.

column3: Title normalization to proper spacing (e.g., ""BatchPartsProcessor"" → ""Batch Parts Processor""). Model option type changed from `MastraLanguageModel` to `MastraModelConfig` across all processors. Model references updated from dynamic function calls (e.g., `openai(""gpt-4.1-nano"")`) to string identifiers (e.g., `""openai/gpt-4.1-nano""`). Documentation descriptions reflowed for consistency. Related links updated from ""Input/Output Processors"" to ""Guardrails"". Minor formatting and punctuation adjustments.
Added `BatchPartsProcessor` integration in output processor examples with accompanying narrative about batching for performance. Updated model string references to match new specification format.

Consolidates memory thread listing: replaces get* APIs/handlers with list* variants, swaps paginated params from page/perPage to offset/limit, introduces paginated listThreadsByResourceId across memory/storage layers, updates SDK/types, routes, and tests, and bumps major package versions.

column3: Rename `getMemoryThreads` → `listMemoryThreads`; replace `GetMemoryThreadParams/Response` with `ListMemoryThreadsParams/ListMemoryThreadsResponse` (adds `offset`, `limit`, `orderBy`, `sortDirection`); build `/api/memory/threads` query including `runtimeContext`.

Add abstract `listThreadsByResourceId(args: StorageListThreadsByResourceIdInput): Promise<StorageListThreadsByResourceIdOutput>` to `MastraMemory`; update `MockMemory` constructor signature and implement `listThreadsByResourceId` delegating to storage.
Add `listThreadsByResourceId()` method on `Memory` that delegates to `storage.listThreadsByResourceId` and export related storage input/output types.

Replace `getThreadsHandler`/`getThreadsPaginatedHandler` with unified `listThreadsHandler`; rename params `resourceid` → `resourceId`, `page/perPage` → `offset/limit`; update internal adapter names and error text.

Consolidate routes to a single paginated `/threads` endpoint using `listThreadsHandler`; introduce `offset` (default 0) and `limit` (default 100); remove non-paginated/duplicate route registrations and update param schemas.

Rename `getThreadsHandler` → `listThreadsHandler`; replace `memory.getThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` with `memory.listThreadsByResourceId`; update tests and handler signatures to use `offset/limit` and new types.
Adjust tests: `getMessages`/paginated variants return empty array for empty/whitespace `threadId` instead of throwing; update assertions accordingly.
`useThreads` now calls `listMemoryThreads()` and returns `result.threads` when memory enabled; guards against disabled memory.
Clear mock (`mockFindUser.mockClear()`) before test to reset mock state.
Bumped major versions for @mastra/playground-ui, @mastra/client-js, @mastra/deployer, @mastra/memory, @mastra/server, @mastra/core and documented API renames (get→list) and pagination param changes.

column1: participant API as Memory API Handler
UI->>SDK: listMemoryThreads({resourceId, agentId, offset, limit, orderBy, sortDirection})
API->>Memory: listThreadsByResourceId({resourceId, agentId, offset, limit, orderBy, sortDirection})
Storage-->>Memory: { threads[], pagination: { total, offset, limit } }
- Cross-cutting changes across SDK, core interfaces, memory implementation, deployer/router, server handlers, and tests.

- Pay special attention to: route parameter validation/defaults in deployer/router, runtimeContext encoding in SDK URL, and consistent mapping of page→offset and perPage→limit across call sites and tests.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9508 — Nearly identical: replaces `getThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` with `listThreadsByResourceId` and consolidates thread-list handlers/pagination params.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9496 — Directly related: storage API rename to `listThreadsByResourceId` and updates to types/call sites.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9507 — Related: parallel renames from `get*` → `list*` and related storage/memory type adjustments.
> 🐰 I hopped through code both day and night,
> Changed `get` to `list` and set pagination right,
> Offsets line the threads in song,
> Handlers joined — the routes move strong,
> A rabbit cheers: small hops, big delight! ✨

The PR title ""update handlers to use listThreadsByResourceId"" accurately refers to a real and significant aspect of the changeset. The raw summary confirms that handlers across multiple files are indeed updated to use the new `listThreadsByResourceId` method, which replaces the previous `getThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` method. However, the title captures only one aspect of a broader refactoring that includes consolidating pagination APIs across packages, renaming client SDK methods from `getMemoryThreads` to `listMemoryThreads`, changing pagination parameters from page/perPage to offset/limit, and consolidating multiple route handlers into a unified approach. While the title is specific, accurate, and not misleading, it does not fully summarize the primary architectural change, which appears to be the consolidation of pagination and thread listing APIs across the entire codebase.

Comprehensive semantic renaming of list-related API methods across the Mastra codebase, replacing `get*` method names with `list*` variants. Changes span agents, workflows, tools, and memory APIs across core, client-js, MCP, and server packages, with coordinated documentation and test updates.

column3: Version bump changesets marking minor updates for peer dependencies and major version bumps for all packages with renamed public API functions.
Renamed public methods: `getAgents()` → `listAgents()`, `getWorkflows()` → `listWorkflows()`, `getTools()` → `listTools()`. Private helper methods similarly renamed and internal call sites updated.
Test references and inline documentation updated to reflect new method names; deprecation proxy adjusted to recommend `listAgents()` instead of `getAgents()`.

Public method renames: `getAgents()` → `listAgents()`, `getTools()` → `listTools()`, `getWorkflows()` → `listWorkflows()`, `getAgentsModelProviders()` → `listAgentsModelProviders()` with corresponding type rename.
All test call sites updated to use renamed public methods.
Documentation updated to reflect renamed public API methods.

Exported handler functions renamed: `getAgentsHandler` → `listAgentsHandler`, `getToolsHandler` → `listToolsHandler`, `getWorkflowsHandler` → `listWorkflowsHandler`. Internal calls to Mastra API methods updated accordingly.
Tests updated to reference renamed handlers and verify expected behavior.
Documentation updated to show new handler names.
All test call sites updated to use renamed methods.
API calls updated to use renamed methods; property checks updated for renamed functions.
Peer dependency updated; documentation examples updated to show new method names.
Public method `getTools()` renamed to `listTools()`; peer dependency constraint updated.
Public methods and handlers renamed: `getToolsInputOptions()` → `listToolsInputOptions()`, `getAgentsHandler` → `listAgentsHandler`, etc.; all router bindings updated.
Public and internal methods renamed: `getTools()` → `listTools()`, `getToolsForMode()` → `listToolsForMode()` with call sites updated.
Internal method call updated from `getToolsInputOptions()` to `listToolsInputOptions()`.
Client API calls in React hooks updated to use renamed methods.
All test setup calls updated from `getTools()` to `listTools()`; documentation examples updated.
Internal call updated to use `listWorkflows()` instead of `getWorkflows()`.
Documentation pages and sidebar references updated to reflect renamed methods; code examples and method descriptions updated accordingly.
All documentation updated to show new method names in code examples and descriptions; migration guide updated with new API mapping.
Sidebar metadata updated with new method references and removed old entries.
Example code updated to use renamed API methods.
Template code and documentation updated to reflect renamed methods.
Test and script files updated to use renamed API methods.

**Bump type should be ""major"" for breaking API changes.**

Renaming public API methods (e.g., `getAgents()` → `listAgents()`) constitutes breaking changes for consumers of these APIs. According to semantic versioning, breaking changes require a **major** version bump, not a **minor** bump. A minor bump is reserved for backward-compatible feature additions.
Update the bump type from `minor` to `major` for all three packages to accurately reflect the breaking nature of these API renames:

Renames workflow run API/types from ""Get..."" to ""List..."" and corrects capitalization of storage types; adds Workflow.listWorkflowRuns and updates handlers, routes, client types, core storage types, and multiple storage implementations. No runtime control-flow changes except the new listWorkflowRuns method mirroring prior behavior.

column3: Renamed `GetWorkflowRunsParams`/`GetWorkflowRunsResponse` → `ListWorkflowRunsParams`/`ListWorkflowRunsResponse`; updated `runs()` signature and return types to `ListWorkflowRuns*`.
Updated imports and `listThreadsByResourceId` method signatures to use `StorageListThreadsByResourceId*` types.

Added `async listWorkflowRuns(args?: { fromDate?: Date; toDate?: Date; limit?: number; offset?: number; resourceId?: string; })` delegating to storage or returning `{ runs: [], total: 0 }` when storage is unavailable.
Renamed handler `getWorkflowRunsHandler` → `listWorkflowRunsHandler`; updated imports, tests, router descriptions, and internal calls to use `workflow.listWorkflowRuns`.

This pull request renames the storage API method `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` to `listThreadsByResourceId`, updates associated exported types from `StorageListThreadsByResourceIdPaginated*` to `StoragelistThreadsByResourceId*` across core and backend stores, and adds defensive try/catch handling for paginated message/thread retrieval in the in-memory store; pagination behavior is preserved via delegation.

column3: Renamed exported types: `StorageListThreadsByResourceIdPaginatedInput` → `StoragelistThreadsByResourceIdInput` and `StorageListThreadsByResourceIdPaginatedOutput` → `StoragelistThreadsByResourceIdOutput`; shapes unchanged.
Updated method signatures from `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated(...)` → `listThreadsByResourceId(...)`, updated imports/return types to use the renamed types, and adjusted calls to memory stores.

Replaced public method `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` with `listThreadsByResourceId` (converts `limit/offset` → `page/perPage` and delegates to `getThreadsByResourceIdPaginated`); wrapped paginated message/thread retrieval logic in try/catch to return safe empty paged results on error. Updated tests to expect empty results for invalid `threadId` instead of thrown errors.

Adds new public list APIs across core storage and backend adapters: `listMessages`, `listMessagesById`, `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` (memory stores) and `listWorkflowRuns` (workflows). Most implementations delegate to existing getters; many `listMessages` methods currently throw a not-implemented error. Some files contain duplicate declarations.

column3: New types exported: `StorageListMessagesInput`, `StorageListMessagesOutput`, `StorageListWorkflowRunsInput`, `StorageListThreadsByResourceIdPaginatedInput`, `StorageListThreadsByResourceIdPaginatedOutput`. Added methods to `MastraStorage`: `listMessages`, `listWorkflowRuns`, `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated`, `listMessagesById` (delegate to memory or throw NOT_SUPPORTED).

Added abstract methods on `MemoryStorage`: `listMessages`, `listMessagesById`, `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated`. In-memory impl adds these methods: `listMessages` (throws not-implemented), `listMessagesById` (delegates to `getMessagesById` with format `'v2'`), `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` (converts offset/limit to page/perPage and delegates). Duplicate declarations appear in `inmemory.ts`.
Added `listWorkflowRuns(args?: StorageListWorkflowRunsInput): Promise<WorkflowRuns>` abstract method and in-memory implementation delegating to `getWorkflowRuns`.

Added `listMessages` (throws not-implemented), `listMessagesById` (delegates to `getMessagesById` with `'v2'`), and `listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated` (computes page/perPage from offset/limit and delegates to `getThreadsByResourceIdPaginated`). Several backends include duplicated method declarations in the same file (notably cloudflare, dynamodb, mongodb, upstash, and core inmemory).
Added `listWorkflowRuns(args?: StorageListWorkflowRunsInput): Promise<WorkflowRuns>` wrapper methods delegating to each store's `getWorkflowRuns`.
Bumped package versions/changelogs and widened peer dependency range for `@mastra/core` in memory and server packages.

The PR title ""Stub new list storage api"" is directly related to the main changes in this pull request. The changeset introduces four new public storage API methods (listMessages, listMessagesById, listThreadsByResourceIdPaginated, and listWorkflowRuns) across the storage layer and its multiple implementations. The term ""stub"" accurately describes the implementations, as many methods throw ""not implemented"" errors or simply delegate to existing methods. The title is concise, clear, and specific enough that a teammate scanning the commit history would immediately understand that this introduces new list-based storage API endpoints, albeit as placeholder implementations.

> ## Other AI code review bot(s) detected
> CodeRabbit has detected other AI code review bot(s) in this pull request and will avoid duplicating their findings in the review comments. This may lead to a less comprehensive review.

Adds an end-to-end ""reset agent model"" feature: core stores the original model and exposes an internal reset, server exposes a handler that calls it, deployer adds a POST route, client SDK adds `resetModel()`, and the playground UI adds a hook and wires a reset action into agent metadata components.

column3: Adds a changeset documenting patch bumps and a fix so the reset restores the original LanguageModelV2 (and other types) object passed during agent construction.
Stores the original model in a private `#originalModel` at construction and adds an internal `__resetToOriginalModel()` utility to restore it (cloning arrays to avoid aliasing).
New exported `resetAgentModelHandler({ mastra, agentId })` that resolves the agent and calls `agent.__resetToOriginalModel()`, returning a success message or handling errors.
Adds a wrapper import/export of the server handler and exposes POST `/:agentId/model/reset` route with OpenAPI metadata, bodyLimit, and standardized error handling.
Adds public `resetModel(): Promise<{ message: string }>` which POSTs to `/api/agents/${agentId}/model/reset`.
Adds exported `useResetAgentModel(agentId)` mutation hook that calls the client `resetModel()` and invalidates the `['agent', agentId]` query on success.
Uses `useResetAgentModel(agentId)` and passes the returned `resetModel` into `AgentMetadata`.

`AgentMetadata` and `AgentMetadataModelSwitcher` accept an optional `resetModel` prop; switcher syncs local state with defaults and calls `resetModel()` when resetting (logs a warning if prop missing).

column1: Server-->>API: { message: ""Agent model reset to original"" }
Hook->>UI: invalidate agent query -> UI refreshes
- `packages/core/src/agent/agent.ts`: correct capture/cloning of initial model for single vs multi-model agents and avoidance of aliasing.
- `packages/playground-ui/src/domains/agents/components/agent-metadata/agent-metadata-model-switcher.tsx`: effects that sync defaults to local state and the new reset flow that calls `resetModel()`.
- API wiring and error handling across `deployer -> server -> core` to ensure consistent responses and propagation.
> 🐰 I kept the first model safe, snug like a seed,
> A tiny hop returns what you need.
> Core holds the memory, server sends the call,
> UI taps the button — watch it restore all.
> Hop—your agent's whole heart, back to the start.

The title ""fix: restore original agent model when resetting model in UI"" is concise, specific, and directly captures the main objective of the PR. It clearly communicates that this is a bug fix addressing model reset functionality in the playground UI, specifically restoring the original model object. The title accurately reflects the core changes across multiple packages (core, server, deployer, client SDK, and UI) that work together to implement the described fix. The language is clear and unambiguous, allowing developers scanning the repository history to immediately understand the primary change without being generic or vague.

column1: <sub>Comment `@coderabbitai help` to get the list of available commands and usage tips.</sub>
**Reset may not restore true original; clone the model list and clone on reset**

Currently, for array models `#originalModel = this.model` stores a reference. Subsequent mutations (reorder/update) will alter the “original,” defeating reset. Clone when capturing and when resetting.
+      // Capture an immutable snapshot of the original array config
+    // Restore from snapshot; clone to avoid aliasing future mutations
this.logger.debug(`[Agents:${this.name}] Model reset to original.`, { model: this.model, name: this.name });
Optionally deep-freeze the snapshot in dev builds to catch accidental mutations during development.
In packages/core/src/agent/agent.ts around lines 231-235 (and similarly at lines
995-999), the code assigns array models by reference which allows later
mutations to alter the “original” snapshot; change the capture to clone the
model list (shallow clone like [...model] or a deep clone if nested) when
setting #originalModel and ensure reset replaces this.model with a clone of
#originalModel (not the reference). Optionally, in dev builds wrap the snapshot
with a deep-freeze to catch accidental mutations during development.

9481;greptile-apps[bot];"**logic:** Shallow copy issue with model array. When `config.model` is an array, both `this.model` and `this.#originalModel` reference the same array. The `reorderModels()` method on line 1006 calls `this.model.sort()` which mutates the array in place, affecting both references. This breaks the reset functionality for model arrays that have been reordered.
This is a comment left during a code review.

**logic:** Shallow copy issue with model array. When `config.model` is an array, both `this.model` and `this.#originalModel` reference the same array. The `reorderModels()` method on line 1006 calls `this.model.sort()` which mutates the array in place, affecting both references. This breaks the reset functionality for model arrays that have been reordered.
How can I resolve this? If you propose a fix, please make it concise.

This PR updates peer dependencies across multiple Mastra packages to require @mastra/core version 1.0.0 or higher, aligning with a major version release. Three changesets document the version bumps and removal of legacy evals functionality.

column3: Three new changesets introduced: one documents updating peer dependencies to align with 1.0.0 core package version; another documents major version bumps across numerous Mastra packages and removal of legacy evals; third marks a patch release for memory peer dependency alignment.
Updated @mastra/core peer dependency from `>=0.20.1-0 <2.0.0-0` to `>=1.0.0-0 <2.0.0-0` in both packages.
Updated @mastra/core peer dependency from their previous constraints (`>=0.22.3-0 <0.23.0-0` and `>=0.21.0-0 <2.0.0-0` respectively) to `>=1.0.0-0 <2.0.0-0`.
Extended @mastra/core peer dependency upper bound from `<0.23.0-0` to `<2.0.0-0`, changing constraint from `>=0.22.3-0 <0.23.0-0` to `>=0.22.3-0 <2.0.0-0`.

Removed the evals/evaluation subsystem across the repo: deleted evaluate helpers, Metric types and many LLM/NLP metrics, TABLE_EVALS and legacy-evals storage domains/implementations, hook overloads and hook registrations, eval-related endpoints/tests/docs, and narrowed Agent generic types.

column3: Removed ON_GENERATION / ON_EVALUATION hook registrations and evaluation/storage logic from deployer/server entry templates.
Removed TMetrics generic and evals property from Agent API; removed instructions propagation in prepare-stream workflows.
Deleted evaluate helper, Metric abstract/type exports, EvaluationResult/TestInfo types.
Removed ON_EVALUATION/ON_GENERATION-specific overloads and core eval re-export.
Removed `TABLE_EVALS`, EvalRow types, LegacyEvalsStorage base and abstract APIs; removed TABLE_EVALS from mocks/inits.

column2:
**DB backends: legacy-evals removals**
multiple files under `stores/*/src/storage/domains/legacy-evals/*` and `stores/*/src/storage/index.ts` (clickhouse, cloudflare, cloudflare-d1, dynamodb, lance, libsql, mongodb, mssql, pg, upstash)
column3: Deleted per-backend LegacyEvals storage implementations and removed getEvals/getEvalsByAgentName from stores.
Removed TABLE_EVALS handling in operations, test fixtures, and helper test suites; removed evals test utilities and sample data.
Removed many LLM and NLP metric implementations, judges, prompts, tests, attachListeners/globalSetup, evaluate and re-exports; tsup inputs reduced to scorers and utils; package exports pruned.
Reduced Agent generic arity in public createStep/overloads across workflow modules.
Removed API handlers and routes for eval retrieval (getEvalsByAgentIdHandler, getLiveEvalsByAgentIdHandler); removed eval content from prompts and OpenAPI.
Removed `evals()` and `liveEvals()` client methods and related response type.
Deleted example eval project, removed/rewrote eval docs and references.
Removed `eval` span variant and deleted `EvaluatorCoinIcon` / `ScoreIcon` exports and usages.
Removed eval-related CI step and npm scripts `test:evals:nlp` and `test:evals:llm`.

column1: Note right of Generator #dfe7ff: Old flow (before this PR)
Note right of Generator #f2f6f9: New flow (after this PR)
- Agent generic/API changes: update sites and public SDKs (packages/core, client-sdks).
- Storage removals across all backends (clickhouse, pg, mssql, mongo, ddb, cloudflare, upstash, lance, libsql): verify no leftover TABLE_EVALS refs or conditional key logic.
- packages/evals removals: ensure scorers (llm/code) provide required replacement functionality and package exports/tsup are correct.
- Hook overloads and any code relying on ON_GENERATION/ON_EVALUATION typed payloads.
- OpenAPI and server route removals: client compatibility and docs generation.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9280 — touches MSSQL legacy-evals transform logic; likely to conflict with this PR's MSSQL legacy-evals removal.
> I thumped my paw, the hooks are gone,
> No evals to count at early dawn.
> Scorers hop in, tidy and bright,
> I munch the old traces—soft moonlight.
> A rabbit cheers the code made light. 🐇""

The pull request title ""Part 1: Remove legacy evals"" accurately and directly reflects the main change in the changeset. The PR systematically removes evaluation-related functionality across the codebase, including the `Metric` type, `evaluate` function, evaluation hooks, storage for evals (`TABLE_EVALS`, `EvalRow`, `LegacyEvalsStorage`), all LLM and NLP metrics, evaluation routes/handlers, and related test utilities. The title is specific and clear—""legacy evals"" meaningfully identifies what is being removed—and the ""Part 1"" qualifier appropriately indicates this is a multi-part refactoring effort. A teammate scanning the commit history would immediately understand that this PR removes outdated evaluation infrastructure.

**Await and handle runExperiment to avoid unhandled rejections**

runExperiment is async and returns a Promise. Not awaiting/handling it can cause unhandled rejections and flaky test execution/early process exit. Wrap with an async IIFE and try/catch (TS/Node‑compatible) and log results.
-  data: [{ input: 'Can you tell me what recent YC companies are working on AI Frameworks?' }],
+      data: [{ input: 'Can you tell me what recent YC companies are working on AI Frameworks?' }],
Optional: add onItemComplete to inspect each item’s target/scorer outputs for debugging.
call to runExperiment is not awaited or handled which can lead to unhandled
promise rejections and flaky test exits; wrap the call in an async IIFE (or make
the enclosing function async), await runExperiment inside a try/catch, and log
success/errors via console.error/console.log; optionally pass an onItemComplete
handler to inspect item/target/scorer outputs for per-item debugging.

Refactors and reorganizes Agent tests: adds version-aware mock helpers, introduces three dedicated test suites (scorers, tool-handling, uimessage) parameterized over v1/v2, removes the corresponding tests from the main agent.test.ts, consolidates memory imports, and tweaks MockMemory.saveMessages parameter handling.

column3: New tests validating scorer output data, override behavior, stream execution, and name-to-scorer resolution; parameterized over v1 and v2.
New tests for tool name collision, sanitization, prefixing, truncation, and agents-as-tools scenarios; parameterized over v1 and v2.
New tests for UIMessageWithMetadata across generate/stream paths, metadata preservation, and mixed-message handling; parameterized over v1 and v2.
Removed scorer, tool-handling, UIMessageWithMetadata, and several end-to-end tests now moved to dedicated files.
Consolidated multiple type imports into a single import from `@mastra/core/memory`.
Removed `memoryConfig` and default `format` from runtime destructuring in `saveMessages` while keeping type annotations; runtime still saves as v2.

The PR title ""more agent test moves"" accurately describes the primary change in the changeset. The modifications involve reorganizing agent-related tests by moving large test suites from the main agent.test.ts file into dedicated, specialized test files (scorers.test.ts, tool-handling.test.ts, and uimessage.test.ts). The title is concise, clear, and avoids vague terms or noise. While it could theoretically be more specific about which tests are being moved, it effectively communicates the essence of the refactoring at an appropriate level of detail for a PR title, and the description corroborates this as ""more test separation.""

This PR updates the core memory module to export mock utilities and refactors the message deletion API. It introduces a new `MessageDeleteInput` type, updates method signatures in `MockMemory` for better flexibility, and reorganizes type exports across the memory and core packages. Test files are updated to use `MockMemory` instead of manual mocking.

column3: Version bump records for peer dependency alignment to 0.22.3 and patch updates for @mastra/memory, @mastra/server, and @mastra/core with note ""Use memory mock in server tests"".
Added `MessageDeleteInput` type allowing string IDs or ID objects; exported mock module from index; updated `MastraMemory.deleteMessages()` signature to accept `MessageDeleteInput`.

Refactored `saveMessages()` to accept object with format option (defaults to 'v1'); added new `query()` method returning multiple message formats; updated `getThreadsByResourceId()` to accept sort options; updated `deleteMessages()` to accept `MessageDeleteInput`; enhanced imports for new type support.
Updated @mastra/core peer dependency from `>=0.20.1-0 <2.0.0-0` to `>=0.22.3-0 <0.23.0-0`; moved `MessageDeleteInput` type import from local definition to @mastra/core/memory.
Replaced manual `MastraMemory` mocking with instantiated `MockMemory` in test setup; updated `createThread()` helper to use `StorageThreadType`; adjusted assertions to verify actual memory state.

column1: - **packages/core/src/memory/mock.ts**: Review logic changes in `saveMessages()` with message format conversion and new `query()` method implementation
- **packages/server/src/server/handlers/memory.test.ts**: Verify test refactoring from stub-based mocking to real MockMemory instance is comprehensive and assertions remain valid
- **Type reorganization**: Confirm `MessageDeleteInput` export/import chain across packages is consistent and no type duplication exists
> 🐰 A mock that queries, deletes with flair,
> Types bundled up with utmost care,
> Tests now swift with memory true,
> The core and server aligned anew! ✨

Releases a patch for @mastra/playground-ui fixing an undefined window issue in MainSidebarProvider. Replaces the stateInitializer/localStorage startup read with a stable default state and a post-hydration effect that reads persisted state only when window is available.

column3: Patch release note for @mastra/playground-ui documenting the fix for undefined `window` when Sidebar is used in Next.js

Removed `stateInitializer` and its immediate localStorage read. Initialize state lazily to `'default'`. Add a layout/effect to synchronize persisted `'collapsed'` or `'default'` value after hydration and guard localStorage access with a `window` check. Public API unchanged.

column1: Note over Effect: skip storage read (no-op)
- Review `main-sidebar-context.tsx` for correct use of layout vs effect hooks and dependency array.
- Verify the window guard prevents SSR errors and that localStorage writes/reads are consistent and validated ('collapsed'
- Confirm no public API/signature regressions and that render/hydration mismatches are avoided.
> 🐰 I hopped through code in soft moonlight,
> > Found a window missing from the night,
> > Now state waits till the client wakes,
> > Sidebar snug — both left and right. ✨

The PR title ""[Fix] Undefined window issue when MainSidebar is used on Cloud"" directly corresponds to the main change in the changeset. The summary confirms this is a patch release fixing an undefined window issue when Sidebar is used (specifically addressing hydration mismatch in Next.js), and the code changes in main-sidebar-context.tsx implement this by removing direct window/localStorage access from initialization and deferring it to after hydration via useLayoutEffect. The title is concise, specific to the affected component (MainSidebar), and clearly identifies the problem being solved without vague terminology.

The changes refactor JSON parsing across memory storage layers to use a centralized `safelyParseJSON` utility, replacing ad-hoc inline parsing. Additionally, test validation for empty threadId in `getMessagesPaginated` now uses async error assertions instead of Error constructor spying.

column3: Consolidated JSON parsing into centralized `safelyParseJSON` utility across message transformation pipelines (include/prev/next message handling, thread parsing, updates). Updated content serialization in save/update paths to use `JSON.stringify` uniformly. Removes conditional parsing logic from `getMessages`, `getMessagesPaginated`, and `parseStoredMessage`.
Replaced Error constructor spying with async error assertion pattern using `rejects.toThrowError('threadId must be a non-empty string')` for validation of empty and whitespace-only threadId inputs.

column1: - Verify `safelyParseJSON` utility correctly handles all content types (strings, objects, null) across diverse storage flows to prevent unintended double-quoting or parsing errors
- Confirm that stringified content in save paths maintains backward compatibility with existing stored message formats
- Validate that content field transitions from ad-hoc `typeof` checks to uniform parsing don't introduce edge case regressions in `getMessages` and paginated retrieval flows
- Check test assertion alignment with actual async error rejection behavior
> 🐰 The JSON scattered, now neatly corralled,
> One parser to rule them, no longer enthralled,
> Content flows cleaner through storage's long hall,
> Tests now await errors both big and small! ✨

Consolidates MockMemory from distributed test utilities into a centralized module at `packages/core/src/memory/mock.ts`, updates all test file imports accordingly, introduces comprehensive dynamic memory configuration test coverage, and adjusts peer dependency versioning in the server package.

column3: New file introducing centralized MockMemory class extending MastraMemory with in-memory storage, thread management, message handling (v1/v2), pagination, and placeholder methods for memory operations.
Removed MockMemory class export; retained assertNoDuplicateParts function.

New comprehensive test file covering static/dynamic memory configuration, runtime-context driven resolution, async variants, error handling, system message preservation, and streaming flows for v1/v2 model versions.
Updated MockMemory import paths from local test-utils to centralized `memory/mock`; agent.test.ts additionally removed large dynamic memory test block.
Replaced MockStore with InMemoryStore import and corresponding type/initialization updates.

column1: Test->>Agent: initialize with dynamic memory config
Agent->>Model: generate with system + memory context
Agent-->>Test: generation complete with memory state
- **Dynamic memory test suite** (`dynamic-memory.test.ts`) introduces new, multi-scenario coverage requiring verification of test logic correctness and mock behavior alignment
- **MockMemory consolidation** across multiple test files is largely mechanical (import path updates), but requires cross-file consistency verification
- **Centralized mock implementation** (`memory/mock.ts`) needs careful review for correctness of storage abstractions and method implementations
- **Peer dependency version change** should be validated against actual supported versions and compatibility
> 🐰 A memory refactored, now centered and bright,
> MockMemory hops to a new home at night,
> Tests stream and dance through dynamic flows true,
> System messages preserved in v1 and v2,
> We've organized chaos, the tests now take flight! ✨

Removed network-scoped memory APIs from the JavaScript client SDK: deleted the `NetworkMemoryThread` resource and its tests, removed five network-memory methods and three related parameter types from `MastraClient`, and changed `getMemoryThread` to accept an options object; added `agentId: string` to `CreateMemoryThreadParams`.

column3: Removed network-scoped memory methods and related imports/exports: `getNetworkMemoryThreads`, `createNetworkMemoryThread`, `getNetworkMemoryThread`, `saveNetworkMessageToMemory`, `getNetworkMemoryStatus`, plus removed type imports for network memory params.
Deleted the `NetworkMemoryThread` resource class and its vitest test file (methods: get, update, delete, getMessages, deleteMessages and their tests).
Updated `getMemoryThread` usage/signature from positional `(threadId, agentId)` to single options object `{ threadId, agentId }`; docs example and reference adjusted.

Mutation now uses `client.getMemoryThread({ threadId, agentId })` to obtain a thread instance and calls `thread.delete({ runtimeContext })`; removed networkId-based cache invalidation and network-scoped delete path.
Added a changeset marking a major release and indicating removal of deprecated methods; package metadata adjusted for publish.

column1: Note over UI,Client: New deletion flow (options object)
- Ensure no remaining references to removed types/classes across the SDK and docs.
- Confirm all callers updated to new `getMemoryThread({ threadId, agentId })` shape.
- Verify `CreateMemoryThreadParams` updates propagate to call sites.
- Validate playground UI mutation change and cache invalidation adjustments.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9328 — Modifies the client-js memory API surface and overlaps on memory method signatures and runtimeContext changes.
> I nibbled threads and cleared the lawn,

The title ""remove network threads"" directly and accurately summarizes the primary change in this pull request. The changeset focuses on removing the entire network memory API surface from the client SDK, which includes deleting five network-memory-related methods from MastraClient, eliminating the NetworkMemoryThread resource class, removing associated parameter types, and deleting the corresponding test suite. The title is concise, clear, and specific enough that a teammate scanning the history would immediately understand that network-scoped memory thread operations are being removed from the client SDK.

Updates a GitHub Actions workflow to rename and extend it to regenerate providers and documentation, adding a step that runs a script to produce `docs/public/llms.txt` and `docs/public/llms-full.txt`. The build script now writes outputs under the provided `sourceDir` instead of the process cwd.

column3: Renamed workflow to ""Regenerate Providers & Docs""; changed concurrency group; added step to run `docs/scripts/build-llms-text-files.ts`; extended diff checks to include `docs/public/llms.txt` and `docs/public/llms-full.txt`; add those files to git when changed; updated commit messages and log strings.
Adjusted output path resolution to use the provided `sourceDir` as the base for `public` output (writes to `<sourceDir>/public` instead of `<cwd>/public`).

This PR fixes a bug in system message creation within processors. The processor runner's message enqueuing logic is refactored to distinguish system messages by their role and route them through a dedicated `addSystem` handler instead of the standard message queue.

column3: Adds patch-level changeset documenting fix for system message creation from inside processors via `processInput`.

Refactors message enqueuing to conditionally route system messages (identified by `role === 'system'`) through `addSystem` with extracted text content, while non-system messages are added via standard `add` for the 'input' channel.

column1: Note over Runner: Process each message
Note over Queue: Routes to system channel
Note over Queue: Routes to input channel
- **Conditional routing logic**: Verify the role-based branching correctly identifies and extracts system message content
- **Integration point**: Ensure `addSystem()` method exists and accepts the extracted text parameter
- **Regression risk**: Confirm all existing message types still flow through appropriate queues
> 🐰 A message came lost in the queue,
> System-routed, it knew where to go,
> No more confusion, the fix sets aglow! ✨

Default fastembed now targets AI SDK v5 (AI SDK v2 spec) via a new v2 provider; a legacy v1 provider and legacy exports (`smallLegacy`, `baseLegacy`) were added. README, package.json, integration tests, and a changeset were updated to document and test v2/v1 compatibility.

column3: Added AI SDK v2 (v5) compatibility section, Default (v2) usage example, Available Models (v2 defaults, named v2 exports, legacy v1 exports), Direct AI SDK v5 usage example, and breaking-change guidance.

Upgraded `ai` to `^5.0.76`; added `ai-v4` alias (`npm:ai@4.3.19`); added `@ai-sdk/provider` `^2.0.0`; added `test:fastembed` script and included it in integration test chain; added devDependency in integration tests.

Introduced v2 provider using `customProvider` (AI SDK v5) with doEmbed calling `generateEmbeddings`; added legacy provider using `experimental_customProvider` from `ai-v4`; extended exported `fastembed` object with `smallLegacy` and `baseLegacy` referencing legacy models.

Added Vitest suite validating v2 spec assignability, embedV2 integration with AI SDK v5, v2 named exports, legacy v1 exports and failure modes when mixing specs, multi-value embeddings, determinism, and core integration patterns.
Documented major bump to AI SDK v5 (spec v2), default exports switched to v2, and added legacy v1 export pathways (`smallLegacy`, `baseLegacy`).

column1: participant AIv5 as AI SDK v5
participant AIv4 as AI SDK v4
- `packages/fastembed/src/index.ts`: provider instantiation, doEmbed mapping, model id/spec mapping, and exported legacy references.
- `packages/memory/integration-tests-v5/src/fastembed.test.ts`: test assertions for v2 vs v1 behavior and error paths.
- `packages/fastembed/README.md`: accuracy of usage examples and model listing.
> 🐇 I nibble code at morning's light,
> > v2 hops forward, v1 tucked tight,
> > Tests that prove the pathways guide,
> > Embeddings sprout — I leap in flight!

The PR title ""feat: upgrade @mastra/fastembed to AI SDK v5 specification"" directly and clearly reflects the main change in the changeset. The changes across multiple files—updated dependencies to AI SDK v5, modified index.ts with v2 and legacy providers, comprehensive tests, and documentation—all center on this upgrade. The title is concise, specific, and accurately summarizes the primary objective without vagueness.

The PR comprehensively addresses all objectives derived from issue #8485. The dependency upgrade from AI SDK v4 to v5 is implemented with the ""ai"" package updated to ^5.0.76 and ""@ai-sdk/provider"" added. The codebase now uses v2 specification as default while maintaining legacy v1 exports through smallLegacy and baseLegacy properties. The breaking change is explicitly documented in the changeset as a major version bump, and the README provides clear migration guidance with usage examples for both specifications. Comprehensive integration tests validate both v2 and legacy v1 compatibility, confirming the upgrade works with the latest @mastra/core patterns.

All changes in the PR are directly related to the AI SDK v5 upgrade and maintaining backwards compatibility. The README updates document the new v2 specification and usage patterns; the package.json changes update dependencies and add test scripts; the src/index.ts modifications implement both v2 and legacy v1 providers; the new test suite validates the upgrade; and the changeset documents the major version change. No unrelated or tangential modifications are present in this changeset.

Docs and generator updates: import paths switched to site/theme-scoped components, Callout/Tab usages replaced with Markdown admonitions and TabItem-based Tabs, sidebars generation moved into the docs generator, and a new ZenMux provider (18 models) was added to registry and types.

column3: Adjusted logo/import paths to site-scoped components; replaced JSX `<Callout type=""info"">` with Markdown `:::info` admonitions; minor formatting changes.
Moved component imports to `@site/src`/`@theme`; reworked Tabs to use `TabItem`; converted Callout blocks to `:::info`; updated model/provider counts, some links, and hrefs to absolute site paths.

column2:
**Provider docs — Tabs migration**
`docs/src/content/en/models/providers/*.mdx` (anthropic, cerebras, deepinfra, google, groq, mistral, openai, perplexity, togetherai, xai, and others)
column3: Replaced local `{ Tabs, Tab }` imports with theme-provided `Tabs` and `TabItem` imports across many provider pages.
Updated CardGrid imports to site-scoped paths; added ZenMux provider entry; reflowed sidebar entries from inline to expanded object blocks (no semantic change).
Added ZenMux docs page with overview, quick-start examples, ProviderModelsTable, advanced config (custom headers, dynamic selection), and code samples.

Generator now emits `sidebars.js` instead of `_meta.ts`; updated generated MDX content (Tabs→TabItem, Callout→`:::info`, logo paths → `@site/src`); added `generateSidebarsFile`; renamed provider/gateway generator helpers to return sidebar item arrays; updated exports.
Added `zenmux` provider with 18 models to registry and models map; updated generated `ProviderModelsMap` type to include `zenmux`; some provider model arrays reformatted.
Updated Agent Overview links from `/en/docs/agents/overview` to `/docs/agents/overview`.

This could break type definitions and consumers expecting a string. Verify that:

**Test will fail: agents.test.ts line 112 uses strict equality on apiKeyEnvVar which will break for array values.**

The Netlify change to array is intentional and the codebase is prepared to handle it (embedding-router.ts, deployer handlers, and agents.ts all have defensive checks). However, `agents.test.ts` at line 112 compares `provider.envVar` to `registryEntry.apiKeyEnvVar` using `toBe()`, which performs strict equality. This will fail for Netlify since `[""NETLIFY_TOKEN"", ""NETLIFY_SITE_ID""].toBe([...])` evaluates to false due to reference inequality.
Update the test to use `toEqual()` instead of `toBe()` at line 112, or add conditional logic to handle both string and array comparisons.

9372;coderabbitai[bot];<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: summarize by coderabbit.ai -->
> ## Other AI code review bot(s) detected
> CodeRabbit has detected other AI code review bot(s) in this pull request and will avoid duplicating their findings in the review comments. This may lead to a less comprehensive review.

Adds observe-style streaming and resume support for agent-builder across client SDK, deployer routes, server handlers, tests, and the playground UI; updates template installation processing to accept legacy and VNext stream event formats.

column3: Bumps minor versions for `@mastra/client-js`, `@mastra/deployer`, and `@mastra/server`; documents added observe/stream features.

Adds `createRecordParserTransform` to parse RS-delimited binary chunks; adds `observeStream`, `observeStreamVNext`, `observeStreamLegacy`, and `resumeStream` methods; replaces inline stream parsing with shared transform; adds fetch-mocked tests for new streaming methods.

Adds handlers: `streamLegacyAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `observeStreamLegacyAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `observeStreamAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `observeStreamVNextAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `resumeStreamAgentBuilderActionHandler`; implements chunked streaming with reader loops, abort handling, and forwards `tracingOptions`/`closeOnSuspend`.

Adds routes: `POST /:actionId/resume-stream`, `/:actionId/stream-legacy`, `/:actionId/observe-stream-legacy`, `/:actionId/observe-stream`, `/:actionId/observe-streamVNext`; extends request schemas to include `tracingOptions` and `closeOnSuspend` (VNext).

Exposes new handler wrappers backed by workflow handlers: `streamLegacyAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `observeStreamLegacyAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `observeStreamAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `observeStreamVNextAgentBuilderActionHandler`, `resumeStreamAgentBuilderActionHandler`; switches `streamAgentBuilderActionHandler` to use `workflows.streamWorkflowHandler`; adds tests for new flows.

Extends template install record parsing to handle legacy and VNext shapes; adds `useObserveStreamTemplateInstall` hook and `observeInstall` mutation implementing replay-then-live observe flow with retry/backoff and network-error handling.

Replaces watch-based hook with observe-based one: `useWatchTemplateInstall` → `useObserveStreamTemplateInstall`; renames `watchInstall`→`observeInstall`, `watchStreamResult`→`observeStreamResult`, `isWatching`→`isObserving`; updates auto-resume and rendering logic accordingly.

column1: ClientSDK->>DeployerRouter: POST /:actionId/observe-stream { runId, stream: true, tracingOptions? }
DeployerHandler->>DeployerHandler: decode bytes → split on RS → JSON parse records
DeployerHandler-->>ClientSDK: forward parsed record chunks (chunked JSON messages)
ClientSDK->>ClientSDK: createRecordParserTransform emits parsed records to consumer
- `client-sdks/client-js/src/resources/agent-builder.ts` — TransformStream buffering, RS handling, resume payload shaping.
- `packages/deployer/src/server/handlers/routes/agent-builder/handlers.ts` — reader loop correctness, abort handling, and `tracingOptions`/`closeOnSuspend` propagation.
- `packages/playground/src/hooks/use-templates.ts` — replay-then-live logic, retry/backoff, and multi-format event parsing.
- Router schema additions in `packages/deployer/.../router.ts` — ensure request schema compatibility.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9434 — vNext streaming APIs (observeStreamVNext/resumeStream) that align with the new client/server observe/resume flows.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9431 — workflow-level observe/stream/resume handler changes referenced by the new deployer/server handlers.
> 🐰 I nibble streams both old and new,
> Chunks split by RS, I parse them through.
> I replay the past, then hop to live,
> Resume the run — the logs revive.
> Hooray for streams and crunchy code! 🥕

Adds changelog entry and tests; updates workflow resume logic to treat empty resume steps as a resume, support dot-notation string step IDs for nested workflows, and pass undefined step when resuming the entire nested workflow.

column3: Patch release notes for @mastra/core documenting resume behavior: allow resuming suspended nested workflow steps via dot-notation string or by nested workflow id alone.
Added test for resuming a suspended nested workflow step using only the nested workflow step id; updated an existing test to use dot-path string (`'sub-workflow-2.step-2'`) for resume target.

Detect resume when `resume.steps` is empty or a resume label is present; normalize resume step parameter to support string (dot-notation) and array forms; split dot-notation to resolve nested step ids; pass `undefined` step to `Run.resume` when resuming entire nested workflow and gate runtime input persistence by resume state.

column1: Note over Test,Workflow: Resume using array (existing)
Note over Test,Workflow: Resume using dot-notation (new)
Note over Test,Workflow: Resume entire nested workflow by id (new)
Workflow->>Workflow: normalize -> stepParam undefined (no inner step)
Run->>Run: resume from nested workflow root
- Correct gating of runtimeContext persistence and ensuring `Run.resume` behaves with `step=undefined`.
- Tests in `workflow.test.ts` for coverage of edge cases.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9431: Touches resume/suspend handling in `packages/core/src/workflows/workflow.ts`, overlapping resume detection and step resolution logic.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9454: Aligns resume APIs to accept optional/undefined step parameters, related to passing `undefined` to `Run.resume`.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9453: Also modifies resume behavior around empty/undefined steps and propagation of optional step parameters.
> 🐰 Hopping through code with a cheer,
> Resume a nest with just one name,
> Wake suspended steps back to the game.

`10-10`: **Verify the rationale for disabling retries and consider UX impact.**

The implementation is technically correct, but disabling retries completely removes TanStack Query's default resilience against transient network failures. This could impact user experience if temporary issues occur.
- Is this addressing a specific problem (e.g., expensive API calls, rate limiting, cascading failures)?
- Would a partial retry strategy be more appropriate (e.g., `retry: 1` or a custom retry function)?
- Should this decision be documented in a code comment for future maintainers?
If the model providers endpoint is expensive or has specific failure characteristics that make retries problematic, consider documenting this with a comment:
+   // Disable retries to avoid [specific reason: rate limiting/expensive calls/etc.]

Adds vNext streaming support and tracing/output options across Inngest APIs, exports `AgentStepOptions`, and changes core workflow's private `#streamOutput` to a protected `streamOutput`. Tests expanded to validate vNext streaming, suspend/resume, agents, nested workflows, and event renames.

column3: Adds changeset entries: peer dependency alignment and notes for new `.streamVNext` / `.stream` support and minor/patch releases.
Exports `AgentStepOptions`; converts private `#streamOutput` → protected `streamOutput` and updates all internal accesses.

Extends `InngestRun.start()` / `_start()` and `stream` signatures with `tracingOptions`, `outputOptions`, and `format`; adds `streamVNext` wrapper; threads new fields through execution engine, workflow payloads, steps, agents, and tool writers.

Replaces event type checks (e.g., `step-suspended` → `workflow-step-suspended`) and adds an extensive Streaming (vNext) test suite exercising streaming flows, custom events, suspend/resume, agents, nested/parallel workflows, and result validation.

column1: - `workflows/inngest/src/index.ts`: threading of `tracingOptions` / `outputOptions` / `format` across public and internal flows and step/tool contexts.
- `packages/core/src/workflows/workflow.ts`: private → protected `streamOutput` change and all observe/resume/stream helpers.
- `workflows/inngest/src/index.test.ts`: large new vNext test suite and event type expectations.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9431 — touches `packages/core/src/workflows/workflow.ts` and vNext streaming/resume handling, including `streamOutput` visibility changes.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9259 — overlaps `workflows/inngest/src/index.ts` streaming plumbing, exports, and test/runtime fixes for vNext streaming.
> Beside the stream I watch it flow,
> vNext steps hum and softly glow,

The pull request title ""Inngest workflow stream vnext"" directly corresponds to the main objective of the changeset. The core changes introduce vNext streaming capabilities to Inngest workflows, as evidenced by the extensive modifications to support streamVNext methods, the comprehensive new test suite labeled ""Streaming (vNext)"", and updates to the execution engine and streaming infrastructure. The title is concise, specific, and sufficiently clear that a developer scanning the repository history would immediately understand this PR adds vNext streaming functionality to Inngest workflows. While the title could be marginally more descriptive (e.g., with an action verb), it adequately summarizes the primary change without being vague or misleading.

This PR removes a large collection of documentation files under `docs-new` (agents, auth, deployment, examples, RAG, evals, memory, processors, observability) and updates a redirect validation script to read redirects from `vercel.json` instead of `next.config.mjs`.

column3: Removed example env entries and many .gitignore patterns (files emptied/cleared)
Deleted contributor guide and developer workflow documentation
Removed all agent docs (overview, memory, guardrails, networks, voice, tools/MCP, etc.)
Removed contributing templates, Discord, and licensing docs
Removed deployment overviews and server/web framework guidance
Deleted EC2, AWS Lambda, Azure App Services, DigitalOcean, and cloud-providers overview
Removed serverless platform docs and category metadata (_category_.yml, Cloudflare/Netlify/Vercel docs)
Removed agent example pages (voice, AI SDK v5, calling agents, tools/workflows, MCP, WhatsApp, etc.)
Deleted deployment examples and middleware examples (auth, CORS, logging, custom routes, server deploy)
Removed comprehensive eval/example metric pages (relevancy, bias, completeness, hallucination, etc.)
Removed memory examples for LibSQL, MongoDB, Postgres, Upstash and working-memory patterns
Removed AI tracing example and custom processor examples (message/response length limiters, response validator)
Deleted RAG examples (chunking, embedding, queries, rerankers) and category metadata
Updated redirect-loading source: now reads `vercel.json` and uses `vercelJson.redirects` instead of importing `next.config.mjs`

The PR title ""Kenny/grwth 952 migrate old nextra docs to docusarurus"" is related to the actual changes in the changeset. The bulk of the modifications consist of removing documentation files from the `docs-new/` directory that were previously used with Nextra, including environment files, multiple documentation pages across agents, auth, deployment, examples, RAG, and other feature areas. Additionally, there is a code change to `.github/scripts/validate-redirects.js` that updates the redirect configuration source, which aligns with a documentation platform migration. While the title could be more specific about the scope (the PR primarily involves deletion rather than a complete bidirectional migration visible in this diff), it accurately conveys that this changeset is part of transitioning away from Nextra, and a team member reviewing history would understand this relates to documentation reorganization and migration efforts.

> ## Other AI code review bot(s) detected
> CodeRabbit has detected other AI code review bot(s) in this pull request and will avoid duplicating their findings in the review comments. This may lead to a less comprehensive review.

Refactors parallel/conditional branch shapes to nested `{ type: 'step'; step }` entries, switches execution to direct `StepResult[]`, adds stream error tracking in RunOutput and hardens stream resume/error flows, introduces a centralized toast utility with UI integration, and adds tests for resume error and branching resumes.

column3: Added changeset entries: minor bump for `@mastra/playground-ui` (toast/error note) and patch for `@mastra/core`/`@mastra/inngest` (suspend/resume behavior).
Narrowed `parallel` and `conditional` branch shapes from `StepFlowEntry[]` to `{ type: 'step'; step: Step }[]` and updated serialized equivalents.
Refactored parallel/conditional execution to use nested `step.step` entries and direct `StepResult[]`; updated aggregation, status/output access, invocation sites, and removed wrapper objects.
Added private `#streamError` tracking; capture errors on reject and include error metadata conditionally on finish/resume.
Added try/catch guards around streamVNext/resume handling, added early suspended-status guard in resume flow, and ensured close-stream actions run safely on success/error.
Added negative-path resume test for vNext streaming (resuming non-suspended step errors) and an integration test validating branching resume statuses/results.
Added centralized `toast` built on Sonner with helpers (`success`, `error`, `warning`, `info`, `custom`, `dismiss`, `promise`) and re-exported `Toaster`/`toast` from package index.
Added unified `handleStreamError` that surfaces errors via toast across `streamVNext`/`observeStreamVNext`/`resumeStreamVNext`; replaced some casts with direct `step.step.id` access.
Updated `@mastra/core` peer dependency range in `packages/playground-ui` (minimum bumped) and changeset/package.json churn.

column1: Core->>RunOutput: execute steps (parallel/conditional use nested step.step)
Core-->>UI: update stream output (close if complete)
RunOutput->>Caller: include error in finish metadata

- `packages/core/src/workflows/default.ts` and `workflows/inngest/src/index.ts` — validate all call sites, reductions, and resume paths for the new `{ type: 'step'; step }` shape and direct `StepResult` usage.
- `packages/core/src/stream/RunOutput.ts` and `packages/core/src/workflows/workflow.ts` — confirm error capture, metadata inclusion, and correct close-stream ordering in suspend/resume/error cases.
- UI integration: `use-workflows-actions.ts`, `toast.tsx`, and layout — ensure toasts display correctly and Toaster is not duplicated.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9379 — Overlapping edits to parallel execution/result aggregation in `packages/core/src/workflows/default.ts`.
- mastra-ai/mastra#9259 — Related changes touching Inngest workflow implementation and branching/resume tests.
> 🐰 Streams hop, then clear the night,
> Errors caught and wrapped in light,
> Toasts that tell when trouble grows,
> A rabbit cheers: the workflow flows! 🥕

column4: Check skipped - CodeRabbit’s high-level summary is enabled.

The pull request title ""Prevent changing workflow status to suspended when some parallel steps are still running"" accurately reflects the primary behavioral change in this changeset. The raw summary explicitly confirms this is the main bug fix: the changeset entry states ""prevents changing the workflow status to suspended when parallel steps are still running,"" and the workflow.ts changes add a guard to throw if snapshot status is not 'suspended' during the resume flow. The title is concise, clear, and specific enough for a teammate scanning history to understand the core issue being addressed. While the PR includes additional changes such as toast error handling and refactoring of parallel/conditional logic, the title appropriately prioritizes the main bug fix, which aligns with standard PR practice of not requiring titles to cover every detail.
Docstring coverage is 100.00% which is sufficient. The required threshold is 80.00%.

**Fragile error detection and unsafe type casting.**
The error handling has several issues:
1. **Brittle error filtering**: Using `.toLowerCase()?.includes('releasing default reader')` to identify expected cleanup errors is fragile. Error messages can vary across browsers/runtimes.
2. **Unsafe type casting**: `err as Error` assumes the thrown value is an Error instance. If something else is thrown (string, object, etc.), accessing `.message` could fail.
3. **Code duplication**: This identical pattern appears in lines 247-252, 333-338, and 421-426.
Improve error handling with proper type checking:
+  // Expected error during cleanup - safe to ignore
+  const errorMessage = err instanceof Error ? err.message : 'Error streaming workflow';
Better yet, extract this to a reusable helper:
// Expected error during cleanup - safe to ignore
const errorMessage = err instanceof Error ? err.message : defaultMessage;
around lines 247-252 (and similarly update the duplicated blocks at 333-338 and
421-426), the catch block unsafely casts err to Error and relies on a fragile
substring match of the message; instead extract a reusable helper (e.g.,
handleStreamError) that accepts err: unknown and a defaultMessage, checks for
expected cleanup errors using safe type checks (for example if err instanceof
DOMException && err.name === 'TypeError' or other reliable runtime-specific
conditions) and otherwise derives the message with err instanceof Error ?
err.message : defaultMessage and calls toast.error; replace the three duplicated
catch blocks with calls to this helper to remove unsafe casting and duplicate

Adds Docusaurus i18n and GT configs, many new English and Japanese translation resources, extensive Japanese localized documentation and examples across agents, auth, deployment, RAG, memory, evals, observability, and several example implementation files exporting constants used by the docs.

column3: Added Docusaurus i18n block (defaultLocale: `en`, locales: [`en`,`ja`]) and a GT config with output paths, locale restriction to `ja`, and experimental options.
New English translation resource files for theme strings, plugin content labels, footer, and navbar alt text.
New Japanese translation resource files for theme strings and content/sidebar labels.
Many new Japanese agent docs: voice, memory, guardrails, networks, overview, tools & MCP, examples and usage guides.
Added Japanese docs for JWT, Supabase, Firebase, Auth0, Clerk, WorkOS and auth index.

New Japanese deployment guides for cloud providers (EC2, Lambda, Azure, DigitalOcean), server deployment, monorepo guidance, serverless platform guides (Cloudflare, Netlify, Vercel), and category metadata.

column2:
**Japanese docs — Examples (Agents, RAG, Memory, Evals, Observability, etc.)**
`docs-new/i18n/ja/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/examples/**`
column3: Large set of localized example pages: agents (voice, image, supervisor, tools, workflows), RAG chunking/embedding/query/upsert/rerank, memory backends and working-memory templates, evals/Scorers examples, observability/tracing, middleware and deployment examples, indexes and category YAMLs.

Added example implementation files referenced by docs that export constants/instances (e.g., `copywriterAgent`, `copywriterTool`, `editorAgent`, `editorTool`, `publisherAgent`, `mastra`, `upstashAgent`).

column1: Areas to focus on during review:
- Spot-check newly exported example code files for correct exports, types, and accidental production-facing API changes (see `src/mastra/...` added files).
- Validate i18n and GT config mapping and output paths match Docusaurus expectations.
- Sanity-check representative code snippets in key Japanese docs for syntax correctness (agents/voice, RAG examples, memory backends).
- Verify `_category_.yml` positions and sidebar label consistency to avoid ordering/label drift.
- Check links and cross-references in Japanese docs point to intended localized paths.

The PR title refers to real components of the changeset: the addition of the ""experimentalClearLocaleDirs"" flag to gt.config.json is present, and the PR does include extensive i18n configuration and Japanese documentation files. However, the title has two concerns: first, ""i18n of new docs"" is somewhat vague and doesn't clearly convey that extensive Japanese documentation has been added across multiple categories (agents, auth, deployment, evals, memory, RAG, etc.); second, the emphasis appears disproportionate—the gt config change is brief while the overwhelming majority of changes are new Japanese documentation files, yet the title mentions the config flag first. A teammate scanning git history would see this title and might not fully appreciate the scope of the documentation addition.
